channel.title: LOVE & Bubbles..?
channel.description:
So I haven't made anything in ages, but I made these in the past 2 days.
With the bubbles, I was just experimenting... And I needed a background for my phone. [IMG]http://img150.imageshack.us/img150/6898/88577868.png[/img]
With LOVE, I was just remaking an old LP, which I had never gotten around to earlier. [IMG]http://fc06.deviantart.com/fs46/i/2009/183/d/4/LOVE_by_FastBawlz.jpg[/img]

item.title: LOVE & Bubbles..?
item.dc:creator: @Full_Metalst Full Metalst
item.description:
@Full_Metalst wrote:

[quote=“SomethingToHide, post:11, topic:286413”]Don’t use gaussian blur, especially for DOF type blurring. Always use lens blur for that.

I don’t like the bubbles one. It’s like there’s three layers of bubbles, and each layer is perfectly flat in the Z direction. The blur makes it seem like you were going for depth, and if you were your combination of blurring, lighting, and size failed at it.

The bubbles wouldn’t in all the same location on the Z axis in each layer, so the ones farther away and closer would have varying levels of out-of-focus-ness.

Then the lighting makes it almost impossible to tell which layer is closer and blurred than which is farther and blurred. The lighting makes the front and back bubbles almost the same group of colors so there’s another faking-perspective rule broken.

And then the blurred ones are pretty much of equal size variations. That would mean the ones in front are really small compared to the ones in the middle, and the ones in the back are really big[/quote]
That’s a great way of blurring, didn’t think of lens blur.

Read full topic

item.title: LOVE & Bubbles..?
item.dc:creator: @FastBallz FastBawlz
item.description:
@FastBallz wrote:

[quote=“SomethingToHide, post:11, topic:286413”]Don’t use gaussian blur, especially for DOF type blurring. Always use lens blur for that.

I don’t like the bubbles one. It’s like there’s three layers of bubbles, and each layer is perfectly flat in the Z direction. The blur makes it seem like you were going for depth, and if you were your combination of blurring, lighting, and size failed at it.

The bubbles wouldn’t in all the same location on the Z axis in each layer, so the ones farther away and closer would have varying levels of out-of-focus-ness.

Then the lighting makes it almost impossible to tell which layer is closer and blurred than which is farther and blurred. The lighting makes the front and back bubbles almost the same group of colors so there’s another faking-perspective rule broken.

And then the blurred ones are pretty much of equal size variations. That would mean the ones in front are really small compared to the ones in the middle, and the ones in the back are really big[/quote]

I wasn’t going for realism, I was just experimenting.

Read full topic

item.title: LOVE & Bubbles..?
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Don’t use gaussian blur, especially for DOF type blurring. Always use lens blur for that.

I don’t like the bubbles one. It’s like there’s three layers of bubbles, and each layer is perfectly flat in the Z direction. The blur makes it seem like you were going for depth, and if you were your combination of blurring, lighting, and size failed at it.

The bubbles wouldn’t in all the same location on the Z axis in each layer, so the ones farther away and closer would have varying levels of out-of-focus-ness.

Then the lighting makes it almost impossible to tell which layer is closer and blurred than which is farther and blurred. The lighting makes the front and back bubbles almost the same group of colors so there’s another faking-perspective rule broken.

And then the blurred ones are pretty much of equal size variations. That would mean the ones in front are really small compared to the ones in the middle, and the ones in the back are really big

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @eVokki1 Cowie`
item.description:
@eVokki1 wrote:

You could layer it slightly, sanga. At the simplest level make two layers of bubbles with the secondary one having a blur (Possibly gaussian (sp?)) and a lowered opacity, then put it below the other.

is that bubbles one as simple to make as it looks? Gradient background, a few bubbles with opacity set down some with a stroke(maybe all i can tell) and blurring ones that are in the distance and maybe a few lighting effects thrown in here and there? I might give it a go and see where it gets me
